p: Being a developing country, Ethiopia’s agriculture contributes about 42–45 % to its gross domestic product, employs more than 80 % of the population and generates more than 85 % of foreign exchange earnings (Deressa 2007; Gebreegziabher et al. 2011; You and Ringler 2011). By 2020 in Ethiopia, however, yields from agriculture could fall by 50 % because of the adverse effects of climate change like rise in temperature, drought, flood, erratic rainfall and others (FDRE 2011). Climate change has been recognized as having potentially severe impacts on livelihood and development (Mengestu 2011). Tigray is one of the nine Regional States in Ethiopia that is being affected by recurrent drought because of both its arid and semi arid nature (Deressa et al. 2008). Consequently, the impacts of climate change and variability remain a serious challenge.
